chapter.title: Bean Validation Integration
chapter.para: Bean Validation (JSR-303) is a specification introduced as a part of Java EE 6. It aims to provide a standardized way of validating the domain model across all application layers.
The Seam REST module follows the Bean Validation specification and the incoming HTTP requests can be validated with this standardized mechanism.

sect1.title: Validating HTTP requests
sect1.para: Firstly, enable the ValidationInterceptor in the beans.xml configuration file.
Then, enable validation of a particular method by decorating it with the @ValidateRequest annotation.
Now, the HTTP request's entity body (the incomingTask parameter) will be validated prior to invoking the method.

sect2.title: Validating entity body
sect2.para: By default, the entity parameter (the parameter with no annotations that represent the body of the HTTP request) is validated. If the object is valid, the web service method is executed. Otherwise, a ValidationException exception is thrown.
The ValidationException exception is a simple carrier of constraint violations found by the Bean Validation provider. The exception can be handled by an ExceptionMapper or Solder exception handler.

Seam REST comes with a built-in ValidationException handler, which is registered by default. The exception handler converts the ValidationException to an HTTP response with the 400 (Bad request) status code. Furthermore, it sends messages relevant to the violated constraints within the message body of the HTTP response.

example.title: HTTP response
example.programlisting:
HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request Content-Type: application/xml Content-Length: 129
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?> <error> <messages> <message>Name length must be between 1 and 100.</message> </messages> </error>

sect2.title: Validating resource fields
sect2.para: Besides the message body, the JAX-RS specification allows various parts of the HTTP request to be injected into the JAX-RS resource or passed as method parameters. These parameters are usually HTTP form parameters, query parameters, path parameters, headers, etc.

example.title: JAX-RS resource

sect2.para: If a method of a resource is annotated with an @ValidateRequest annotation, the fields of a resource are validated by default.

important.para: Since the JAX-RS injection occurs only at resource creation time, do not use the JAX-RS field injection for other than @RequestScoped resources.

sect2.title: Validating other method parameters
sect2.para: The JAX-RS specification allows path parameters, query parameters, matrix parameters, cookie parameters and headers to be passed as parameters of a resource method.

example.title: JAX-RS method parameters

note.para:
Currently, Seam REST validates only JavaBean parameters (as opposed to primitive types, Strings and so on). Therefore, to validate these types of parameters, either use resource field validation described in
or read further and use parameter objects.

sect2.para: In order to prevent an oversized method signature when the number of parameters is too large, JAX-RS implementations provide implementations of the Parameter Object pattern . These objects aggregate multiple parameters into a single object, for example RESTEasy Form Object or Apache CXF Parameter Bean . These parameters can be validated by Seam REST. To trigger the validation, annotate the parameter with a javax.validation.Valid annotation.

sect1.title: Using validation groups
sect1.para: In some cases, it is desired to have a specific group of constraints used for validation of web service parameters. These constraints are usually weaker than the default constraints of a domain model. Take partial updates as an example.

example.title: Employee.java

sect1.para: The Employee resource in the example above is not allowed to have the null value specified in any of its fields. Thus, the entire representation of a resource (including the department and related object graph) must be sent to update the resource.

When using partial updates, only values of modified fields are required to be sent within the update request, while the non-null values of the received object are updated. Therefore, two groups of constraints are needed: group for partial updates (including @Size and @Email, excluding @NotNull) and the default group (@NotNull).

callout.para: The @GroupsSequence annotation indicates that both validation groups are used by default (for example, when persisting the entity).

sect1.para: Finally, the ValidationInterceptor is configured to validate the PartialUpdateGroup group only.
